articles.headline: Star Witness in Apple Lawsuit Is Still Steve Jobs
articles.snippet: The Apple co-founder’s emails in past lawsuits — a mix of blunt threats and cheery financial promises — have made him an exceptional witness against his own company, even from beyond the grave.
articles.abstract: The Apple co-founder’s emails in past lawsuits — a mix of blunt threats and cheery financial promises — have made him an exceptional witness against his own company, even from beyond the grave.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Three years after his death, Steve Jobs is very much a presence in courtrooms across the country.

articles.headline: A Last Hurrah for ‘Night at the Museum’ Franchise, and for Robin Williams
articles.snippet: “Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb,” which opens in the United States on Dec. 19, features Robin Williams in his final film role.
articles.abstract: “Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb,” which opens in the United States on Dec. 19, features Robin Williams in his final film role.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After wrapping his last shot of Robin Williams in “Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb” in May, Shawn Levy, the movie’s director, joined Ben Stiller, its star, in an on-set tribute to Mr. Williams.

articles.headline: Black Friday Fatigue? Thanksgiving Weekend Sales Slide 11 Percent
articles.snippet: Sales were estimated to have dropped to $50.9 billion from $57.4 billion last year, puzzling experts who predicted strong growth.
articles.abstract: Sales were estimated to have dropped to $50.9 billion from $57.4 billion last year, puzzling experts who predicted strong growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: Have Americans finally had enough of Black Friday madness?

articles.headline: When the Forces of Media Disruption Hit Home
articles.snippet: The Internet lowered the barriers to entry for journalism. This has been great for consumers but not the traditional news industry, whose inefficiencies were profits by another name.
articles.abstract: The Internet lowered the barriers to entry for journalism. This has been great for consumers but not the traditional news industry, whose inefficiencies were profits by another name.
articles.lead_paragraph: I’ve been around long enough to have once marveled at the improbability of the fax machine — that can’t be real! — but I like to think of myself as modern. Which should mean that I’m a big fan of disruption, but that depends on who is being disrupted, doesn’t it?

articles.headline: Boehner Uses New Mandate to Muffle Talk of a Shutdown
articles.snippet: Speaker John A. Boehner is working to persuade Republicans that engaging in a politically explosive spending confrontation is the wrong way to counter the White House.
articles.abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner is working to persuade Republicans that engaging in a politically explosive spending confrontation is the wrong way to counter the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John A. Boehner does not want to be remembered as the Shutdown Speaker.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Working the Land and the Data
articles.snippet: Technology offers some family-owned farms an opportunity to thrive and compete with giant agribusinesses.
articles.abstract: Technology offers some family-owned farms an opportunity to thrive and compete with giant agribusinesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEESBURG, Ind. — Kip Tom, a seventh-generation family farmer, harvests the staples of modern agriculture: seed corn, feed corn, soybeans and data.

articles.headline: West Virginia Coal Country Sees New Era as Donald Blankenship Is Indicted
articles.snippet: Deadly coal mining disasters are nothing new to West Virginia, but a 2010 explosion is different in one important respect: A chief executive is being charged over the 29 lives lost.
articles.abstract: Deadly coal mining disasters are nothing new to West Virginia, but a 2010 explosion is different in one important respect: A chief executive is being charged over the 29 lives lost.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHITESVILLE, W.Va. — On a memorial to West Virginia’s most recent mining disaster, the silhouettes of 29 figures are etched into black granite, men posed with arms around each another like teammates.

articles.headline: An Art Form Rises: Audio Without the Book
articles.snippet: “The Starling Project,” a thriller by Jeffery Deaver, went straight to audiobook on Audible. In fact, Mr. Deaver’s story will not be appearing in print at all.
articles.abstract: “The Starling Project,” a thriller by Jeffery Deaver, went straight to audiobook on Audible. In fact, Mr. Deaver’s story will not be appearing in print at all.
articles.lead_paragraph: Print has been good to Jeffery Deaver. Over the last 26 years, Mr. Deaver, a lawyer-turned-thriller writer, has published 35 novels and sold 40 million copies of them globally.

articles.headline: Ebola Now Preoccupies Once-Skeptical Leader in Guinea
articles.snippet: President Alpha Condé, whose bureaucracy once played down the Ebola epidemic to avoid scaring investors, has become aggressively involved in the fight.
articles.abstract: President Alpha Condé, whose bureaucracy once played down the Ebola epidemic to avoid scaring investors, has become aggressively involved in the fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: CONAKRY, Guinea — The phone rang. It was the president. “The ambulances? Yes, excellency, we need at least 15 to cover our needs,” the nation’s harried Ebola czar answered.

articles.headline: Gregarious and Direct: China’s Web Doorkeeper
articles.snippet: Lu Wei, as the country’s new Internet czar, is the ambassador of a policy in which Beijing claims the right to censor content and track users.
articles.abstract: Lu Wei, as the country’s new Internet czar, is the ambassador of a policy in which Beijing claims the right to censor content and track users.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When a major Chinese-American Internet conference convenes in Washington on Tuesday, a middle-aged Communist Party propaganda chief will be seated amid a room full of tech industry executives, American officials and web luminaries.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: Hackers Using Lingo of Wall St. Breach Health Care Companies’ Email
articles.snippet: Using flawless English and an insider’s knowledge of Wall Street, the cybercriminals have gained access to the inboxes of top health care executives.
articles.abstract: Using flawless English and an insider’s knowledge of Wall Street, the cybercriminals have gained access to the inboxes of top health care executives.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For more than a year, a group of cybercriminals has been pilfering email correspondence from more than 100 organizations — most of them publicly traded health care or pharmaceutical companies — apparently in pursuit of information significant enough to affect global financial markets.
